instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1286: What is A1286? A1286 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Unibody from years Late 2008, Mid 2009, Mid 2009 , Mid 2010, Early 2011, Late 2011, Mid 2012 with EMC 2255, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-2330, 820-2532, 820-2523, 820-2533, 820-2850, 820-2915, 820-3330..
definitions.820-3330: What is 820-3330? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no image
threads.message:
Hi,

I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> that seams to have a bad GPU. CPU gets, hot, I have fan spin, no USB activity and all voltages are present on big coils.

Is there any way to "temporary" disable the GPU, to be sure that the problem is the GPU?

Is there any other way to troubleshoot this problem?

Tks

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no image
threads.message: You can disable GPU in BIOS, with Medusa programmer.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no image
threads.message:
Tks. Already done and I also remove  <RESISTOR>R8901</RESISTOR> (This is an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B board), but it doesn't boot.

However, now i get 0V on L7550/60, and they seam to be shorted (1ohm to ground and 0.003 on diode mode)

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no image
threads.message:
BIOS mod doesn't work with 3330 board!
Check what happened to get short on both coils.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no image
threads.message:
OK. Didn't know about BIOS mod and 3330 board.
I checked everithing and nothing is out of place. I don't think that it was something that i did. Shel I inject some voltage on them to try to figure out what gets hot?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no image
threads.message: Lift the coils one side and check where the short remain.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no image
threads.message:
Tks.
The short is on the <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG2</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>1_L</SIGNAL> (1.5 ohm to ground and 0.003 in diode mode)
I supose that i should remove <RESISTOR>R7550</RESISTOR>/60. Am I correct?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no image
threads.message: I bet the short remains on the CPU side...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no image
threads.message:
Yes, it was a shorted CPU.
Tks.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no image
threads.message: Normal to have 1-2 ohms on iGPU VCore for Ivy Bridge. iGPU VCore voltage is not expected to be present.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no image
threads.message: The board turns on like in first post now?
